items.content_html:
FF110 adds support for serializing the stack for native error types in workers - which means that cloning error stacks now works wherever the structured cloning algorithm is used, not just main threads (support for that was added in FF104).

This adds a release note.

Other docs work can be tracked in #23686
items.title: FF110 Relnote- structured cloning error stack in workers

items.content_html:
Fixes #22560, in which is is reported that submitting the form breaks the example because the server returns 403.

I don't really love this fix, but I don't think we can make this work as a live sample given CSP constraints, and I don't think it is very useful as a live sample anyway without being part of a larger example (with, say, some server-side component).
items.title: Fix issue 22560: remove live sample

items.content_html:
This PR updates the MDN page to use the GitHub-hosted examples which were added in mdn/dom-examples#200, so the examples work properly. Fixes #23394.

  • changes EmbedLiveSample to EmbedGHLiveSample
  • fixes paths to paint worklet
  • fixes an error in inputArguments in the last paint worklet
  • a few copy-edits, in particular one place in the last example where there was some odd repetition, like a copy/paste thing gone wrong. Please check I've not mangled the sense of this.

cc @Rumyra .

Description

Move content of openOrClosedShadowRoot into dom namespace (according to suggestions in #23711)

  • redirect is added
  • a dom page is added as previously there's no such page
  • content in the openOrClosedShadowRoot is edited to reflect the description of the dom.openOrClosedShadowRoot method
  • add a note about Firefox's Element.openOrClosedShadowRoot

Motivation

Fix BCD and related issues for openOrClosedShadowRoot

Additional details

Content is based on

  • https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/reference/dom/
  • https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/fe6e27d68a44c714dcce906749390378ede7d423

Related issues and pull requests

items.title: move Web/API/Element/openOrClosedShadowRoot

items.content_html:
FF110 adds support for Navigator.getAutoplayPolicy(). This allows a developer to check whether a specific media element or audio context can autoplay. You can also check the general policy of whether they will autoplay.
This was needed because previously you had to start the element and check the play state to work out whether autoplay was blocked or not.

The bugzilla issue is https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1773551

Note that this is still in draft:

  • I am still waiting on confirmation of how parts of this works
  • Also have to update the "Autoplay guide for media and Web Audio APIs"

Other docs work can be tracked in #23676
items.title: Navigator.getAutoplayPolicy() docs

items.content_html:
Description

Annotate WebExtension API processId with "optional" and "deprecated" labels and explain that this attribute is no longer supported.

Motivation

This attribute existed in earlier versions of Chromium and was basically a leaky abstraction of Chromium multi-process architecture. It is no longer set on any objects created by the browser (returned by the APIs) and is ignored when user passes them to chromium APIs.

Additional details

In Chromium, it is possible to pass processId to webNavigation.getAllFrames() and webNavigation.getFrame() but it has no effect: it is ignored if it is a number and an error is thrown if it is incorrect type (not a number). Firefox never supported this attribute at all.

Related issues and pull requests

N/A
items.title: Update WebExtension API processId

items.content_html:
Description

Document the FormData constructor submitter parameter.

Also add a "Submit button" glossary page and link to it from various places to help facilitate a consistent and complete understanding of what a submit button is :)

Motivation

This is a new feature which should be landing in major browsers soon, so it would be useful to have it documented.

Additional details

Spec: https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/#interface-formdata
Spec PR (merged): whatwg/xhr#366
Chromium implementation: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4189297
WebKit implementation (merged): WebKit/WebKit#9188
Gecko implementation: https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/D167576

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #23917
items.title: Document the FormData constructor submitter parameter

items.content_html:
Description

This PR contains the reference documentation for the CSS Custom Highlight API.

Motivation

The API is now available in Chromium-based browser (Chrome 105+, Edge 105+, etc.), and is behind a flag in Safari.

Additional details

I wrote this blog post last year on css-tricks about it: https://css-tricks.com/css-custom-highlight-api-early-look/

The spec: https://www.w3.org/TR/css-highlight-api-1/

Related issues and pull requests

This fixes mdn/mdn#348

It is also related to this BCD PR (which should ideally land before): mdn/browser-compat-data#18720
items.title: Reference documentation for the CSS Custom highlight API

items.content_html:
I created a test module landing page so we could discuss the CSS module landing page format for the Q1 project openwebdocs/project#147

What do you all think of the format of this CSS module landing page?

Do the headings make sense for the CSS module landing template?

Idea:

  • 3 to 5 paragraphs about the module
  • Example (should this be in line, or have its own h2 level heading?)
  • Things to note, if any, about the module, displayed in the example. This being inline, not its own heading.
  • Reference
    • Properties
    • Data Types
    • Functions, or other important to module reference (if any)
    • Events (if any)
    • Interfaces (if any)
  • Guides (not in this page, but if they were, is this the right spot?)
  • Associated content (not present in all modules, but likely in most)
    • associated properties
    • associated datatypes from other modules
    • associated concepts (things you need to know to get this module to work, such as time or hardware acceleration in animations)
    • glossary terms (is this the right spot?)
  • Specifications (note, w3c/browser-specs#851 should fix the spec name appearing the same for 2 different specs)
  • See also - this would generally be for internal learn, related properties and guides. We don't have anything on blending, so these are external. There's a few internal on the animation page
items.title: Feedback wanted: CSS module landing page

items.content_html:
Description

Address the confusion with CSS variable in #11382 with two examples.

The first example illustrates the point that var() can invoke variables defined in the later part of the same file.
The second example responds to the queries, specifically:

  • Does setting a custom property in one css file allow it's use in other cases files on the same page?
    • Answer: Yes
  • should the custom properties be defined in the first css file loaded?
    • Answer: Not necessarily

Motivation

Add helpful examples

Additional details

Some simple testing done around CSS var:

  • https://tlylt.github.io/web-examples/cssvar/index.html

Other docs:

  • https://blog.logrocket.com/css-variables-scoping/
  • https://css-tricks.com/a-complete-guide-to-custom-properties/#h-credit

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #11382
items.title: Add more examples to illustrate CSS var() usage

items.content_html:
Description

The code sample probably has an erroneous type="module" attribute. Removing it makes it work for me.

Motivation

Hopefully it fixes an error.

Additional details

When the attribute is present I'm getting the following messages in my console (just running firefox on the local files):

Cross-Origin Request Blocked: The Same Origin Policy disallows reading the remote resource at file:///somepath/webgl-demo.js. (Reason: CORS request not http).

Module source URI is not allowed in this document: “file:///somepath/webgl-demo.js”. index.html:6:1

Related issues and pull requests

None.
items.title: Remove type="module" attribute from script tag

items.content_html:
Description

Fixes the order of navigation links in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/Building_blocks

Motivation

According to #22618 "Selectors" should come first, then different types of selectors, and only then "Cascade and inheritance". The order of navigation was broken in the later PR and now it completely misses the different types of selectors. This PR fixes this.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

Together with mdn/yari#8014 Fixes #23645
items.title: Fix order of learn css pages
